caption:
Most people think proper form in squatting is all about looking good. But the truth is, it's about so much more than that.

And it's about developing strength that's not just superficial, but deep-seated and lasting. 💡

But here's the thing: most people get this wrong. They prioritize the superficial over the substantial, sacrificing form for the sake of a few extra reps or a more impressive Instagram post.

But the reality is, poor form is a recipe for disaster.

Take the common mistake of not keeping your back straight. It's easy to get caught up in the excitement of a new workout and slouch your back, but this can lead to a lifetime of back pain and chronic discomfort.

Or what about the mistake of not engaging your core? This can cause your lower back to compensate, putting unnecessary strain on your spine and increasing your risk of injury.

So, what are the three key elements to master the squat? First, you need to engage your core. This means drawing your belly button towards your spine and maintaining a stable pelvis.

This will help you maintain proper posture and prevent your lower back from compensating.

Second, you need to keep your weight in your heels. This means placing your weight on the balls of your feet, rather than your toes.

This will help you maintain balance and generate power through your legs, rather than just your upper body.

And third, you need to lower yourself down slowly and control the movement. This means taking your time and focusing on the eccentric movement, rather than just the concentric.

This will help you build strength and endurance, rather than just raw power.

When you master these three elements, you'll be able to squat with confidence and precision. You'll be able to lift heavier weights, move with more ease, and get the results you want without sacrificing your body.

And that's what it's all about – not just looking good, but feeling strong, capable, and empowered.

Ever feel like you're crushing a squat, but your knees are screaming in protest?

In this video, we're going to break down the three most common mistakes people make when doing squats, and I'll give you some actionable tips on how to fix them. 💡

Mistake #1: Poor Knee Placement

When you're doing a squat, your knees should be in line with your toes. But what happens when your knees start to cave in or point outward?

That's when you know you're making a mistake. When your knees are out of alignment, you're putting unnecessary stress on your joints, and you're increasing your risk for injury.

So, how do you fix it? It's simple: focus on keeping your weight in your heels, not your toes. This will help you maintain proper knee alignment and prevent your knees from caving in.

And remember, it's not just about the knees – it's about the entire lower body. Engage your glutes and hamstrings to help stabilize your body and maintain proper form.

Mistake #2: Bad Back Alignment

When you're doing a squat, your back should be straight and your core engaged. But what happens when your back starts to arch or round?

That's when you know you're making a mistake. When your back is out of alignment, you're putting unnecessary stress on your spine, and you're increasing your risk for injury.

So, how do you fix it? It's simple: focus on keeping your chest up and your shoulders back. This will help you maintain proper back alignment and prevent your back from arching or rounding.

And remember, it's not just about the back – it's about the entire core. Engage your abs and obliques to help stabilize your body and maintain proper form.

Mistake #3: Inconsistent Depth Control

When you're doing a squat, you should be lowering yourself down to a depth that feels comfortable and controlled. But what happens when you're going too deep or not deep too quickly?

That's when you know you're making a mistake. When you're not controlling your depth, you're putting unnecessary stress on your joints, and you're increasing your risk for injury.

So, how do you fix it? It's simple: focus on slowing down your descent and controlling your depth. This will help you maintain proper form and prevent unnecessary stress on your joints.

And remember, it's not just about the depth – it's about the entire movement. Focus on the entire range of motion, from the start to the finish.

Squats are a powerful exercise that can help you build strength, improve your mobility, and boost your overall fitness. But they're only effective if you're doing them correctly.

By avoiding these three common mistakes and focusing on proper form

Most people get this wrong...

You're engaging your core, activating your glutes, and working your legs in a way that's efficient and effective. 💡

But what's the secret to perfect squat form? It's not rocket science, but it does require attention to detail. Here are the 3 keys to unlocking perfect squat form:

Key #1: Foot Position Your feet should be shoulder-width apart, toes pointed straight ahead or slightly outward. This might seem obvious, but it's surprising how many people get this wrong.

Think about it: if your feet are too far apart, you're putting uneven pressure on your knees. If they're too close together, you're limiting your range of motion.

Get it just right, and you'll be able to squat deeper and more efficiently.

Key #2: Knee Tracking Your knees should track over your toes, not extend past them. This is where most people go wrong. They let their knees cave in or extend too far, putting pressure on their joints.

Keep your knees in line with your toes, and you'll be able to lift with confidence and control.

Key #3: Hip Drive Your hips should be the engine of your squat. You should be driving down into the ground with your hips, not just your legs.

This engages your glutes and lower back, helping you lift more efficiently and effectively. Think of it like a big, powerful piston – your hips are the driving force behind every rep.

When you master these 3 keys, you'll be able to squat with confidence and control. You'll be able to lift heavier, recover faster, and make real progress in the gym.

So, what's holding you back? Is it poor form? Lack of confidence?

Take the first step towards unlocking your gains and transforming your squat game.
